awd_titl_txt: NNCI: Cornell Nanoscale Science and Technology Facility (CNF)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cornell Nanoscale Science and Technology Facility (CNF) will provide the nation's researchers with rapid, affordable, hands-on shared access to advanced nanofabrication tools and associated staff expertise that are too expensive for individual universities or small companies to operate and maintain.  Under this National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI) site award, hundreds of engineers and scientists nationwide, from throughout academia, industry, and government, will utilize CNF's unique toolset and technical staff.  The new research and technology development that the CNF makes possible will transform many fields of engineering and science, spanning sensor and actuator arrays for probing how the brain works; improved photovoltaics, batteries, and fuel cells for economical renewable energy; new types of electronic devices that surmount limitations of silicon; fabrication of living tissues and organs; distributed measurement networks for geosciences; microbiome characterization and manipulation; on-chip signal processing with light; precision agriculture using new sensors; low-cost medical diagnoses; and improved quantum devices for utilizing entanglement, to name just a few. The CNF will also organize education and outreach programs targeting a wide range of researchers, undergraduates, and K-12 students and their families, with the broader goals of providing a hands-on research education to a new generation of diverse engineering and science students, facilitating the commercialization of nanotechnology for societal benefit, extending the benefits of nanofabrication to less-traditional areas of research, and interesting more young students in technology and science.

The unique nanofabrication capabilities that the CNF will make available to the nation's researchers include world-leading electron-beam lithography, advanced optical lithography, dedicated facilities for soft lithography, and direct-write tools for rapid prototype development, along with the flexibility to accommodate diverse projects through the ability to deposit and etch a very wide variety of materials. In addition, CNF's experienced, expert technical staff will be solely dedicated to user support.  Engineers and scientists from throughout academia, industry, and government will utilize CNF's resources to fabricate structures and systems ranging from the centimeter scale down to the nanometer scale.  The new research that the CNF makes possible will advance research and development across many fields, spanning electronics, optics, magnetics, mechanical devices, thermal and energy systems, electrochemical devices, fluidics, and the life sciences and bioengineering. Educational and outreach programs are designed to benefit several target audiences.  CNF will teach new nanotechnology researchers to quickly operate at the research frontier through hands-on training on state-of-the-art tools, in-depth minicourses, and subject-area workshops.  Experienced nanotechnology researchers will benefit from advanced technical workshops in partnership with leading tool vendors.  Undergraduate students will participate in blended courses with regional universities and unique summer research experiences. Young K-12 students and their families will be encouraged to become excited about technology and science through CNF's highly-popular Nanooze science magazine and a new partnership with 4-H.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the operation of the Cornell Nanoscale Facility (CNF), one of 16 nodes in the National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure, as an open user facility, accessible to student, government, and industrial researchers, both regionally and nationally.

Nanotechnology is the science and engineering associated with very small structures, structures typically in the 10 to 1000 nanometer range (< 0.00004 inches), more than 10x smaller than a red blood cell. At the nanoscale, materials and structures can exhibit new properties; electrons behave differently, the materials interact with magnetism and light differently, and they can exhibit new mechanical and chemical properties. The promise of nanotechnology thus manifests itself in many fields. The entire microelectronics revolution is based on nanotechnology, for example. But the nanotechnology revolution extends to many other areas as well. CNF has been significantly impactful in the Life Sciences area, which represents ~40% of our users. Within biomedical engineering, for example, nanofabricated channels can be used to manipulate individual cells or even DNA molecules, leading to both new diagnostic devices as well as providing new platforms to study basic biological processes. In other areas, CNF users have developed new photonic devices for manipulating light (most internet traffic is carried by light over optical fibers). In the area of high-power electronics, crucial to wind energy and electric vehicles, CNF users have developed both new materials and new device structures for increased power output and lower costs.

To impact such broad range of fields requires expensive and complex scientific equipment, much more than could be housed in an individual research lab, or even effectively used by a single university.  Hence, the concept of an open user facility, where researchers from many fields and many institutions can come together and get access. CNF has served this niche, at ever decreasing dimensions, for over 40 years. Over 120 major tools with a replacement value of over 100M$ are housed in CNF facilities. This award makes possible the operation of the facility and the technical support of its users. A critical part of that access is access to a trained and supportive technical staff to maintain the equipment, to instruct users, and to provide advanced technical support. This award does not support the research itself; that is supported by separate awards to individual faculty.

Each year of this award, the research of over 500 individual users from over one hundred institutions was enabled by the Cornell nanoscale facility.  Over the award period,  this award made possible research at 62 different academic institutions

CNF is a major engine of economic development, both regionally and nationally. One hundred twenty different companies (equally divided between large and small companies) have used CNF for research/development over the course of this award. Access to CNF resources is particularly critical to small businesses, who have neither the capital or the time to invest in advanced laboratory equipment. Over the period of this award, CNF has resulted in 15 start-up companies, many of them based on technology developed within CNF.

Technical Merit

The technical accomplishments under this award are too numerous to itemize.  The 2400 journal publications, presentations, and patents/patent applications over the course of the award testify to the scientific merit of the work enabled by the Cornell Nanoscale Facility.

Broader Impacts:

Under this award, CNF has had a major impact on the human resources pipeline. In addition to training over 800 new research users during the award, CNF conducted a variety of education and outreach activities to reach all levels from K-16 and beyond, a total of 713 formal and informal events with over 17,000 participants over the course of the award (not counting Nanooze). The CNF REU program provided early career research experiences to 19 undergraduates. Historical data shows that more than 50% of NNCI/NNIN’s REU students go on to earn Ph.D.s, with more than 90% remaining in a STEM career after 5 years. Each year of the award CNF conducted an international REU program in cooperation with the National Institute for Materials Science in Japan with a total of 20 students. This highly impactful program gives talented undergraduates a more advanced research experience in an international environment, building the critical intercultural skills that are necessary for research in the 21st century. CNF partnered with NYS 4H to deliver nanotechnology activities to NYS youth. CNF conducted its 3 day Technology and Characterization at the Nanoscale (TCN) short course, semiannually, with a total of 300 participants. And finally, the most far reaching outreach activity was Nanooze, our science magazine for young (middle school) students. Over 100,000 copies of each issue of Nanooze are printed and distributed to classrooms around the country. Content is also available on the Nanooze web site at www.nanooze.org. 

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2021
Modified by: Christopher K Ober
